Paragraphs: FROM._THE_PRESIDENT.
MoT_DU_PRESIDENT.
S ummer has arrived and with it comes our annual

convention, hosted by The Halifax Regional
Coin Club. I look forward to seeing each of you
there for an exciting week.
The Convention Organizing Committee, led by
James Williston, has been working diligently with our
hosts to plan and deliver an outstanding programme
that includes tours and visits, a numismatic
workshop,educational seminars, youth activities, a
bourse, Authors  Alley, club meetings, an awards
banquet, and more. Details online at: www.rena.
ca/2023/.
This year s convention will also feature the
election of a new Board of Directors, the results to
be announced during the Annual General Meeting
(AGM) on Saturday, July 22. I encourage each
member to vote for the representatives who will lead
the RCNA for the next two years by completing and
submitting your ballot.
The past year has been an eventful one for our
Association.
  The end of all pandemic restrictions enabled us
to resume gathering in person.

The Ottawa Numismatic Society hosted a highly
successful convention, one of the most profitable
in recent times.

With the support of the Calgary Numismatic
Society, the Nickle Galleries of the University
of Calgary purchased the RCNA library. The
RCNA material plus the numismatic material of
the Nickle Galleries will soon be available to all
our members via inter-library loan at their local
library.

For the first time in many years, we ended our
Fiscal Year in the black.

Thank you and congratulations to each of you who
volunteered and contributed in so many ways to make
it a great year.

While summer often brings a hiatus in club
meetings, it also signals an upswing in shows and
auctions. Now is a great time to attend a show to
find those items missing from your collection. You
may also consider combining vacation plans with
your numismatic interests to make it a family event.
Whatever you decide, have a great summer!

CONVENTION. COMMUNIQUE _DU_CONGRES

Halifax Convention Plans A Wide Range Of Tours  
Le congr s de l ARNC a Halifax pr voit une vari t  de visites

Here is the final instalment of the activities and
H events you want to put on your to-do list while

attending this year s RCNA Convention this
July in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

Tuesday, July 18   Bluenose II sailing and tour of
Lunenburg

At 9 a.m., we leave the Westin Nova Scotia Hotel and travel
for 70 minutes to Lunenburg. We will have approximately
2.5 hours to tour downtown Lunenburg before we enjoy the
2-hour sail on the Bluenose II and experience the sights,
smells and sounds of sailing on a Grand Banks fishing
schooner. Lunenburg is a designated UNESCO World
Heritage site, and 70% of the original colonial buildings
from the 18th and 19th centuries are still standing and are
used by various shops and businesses.

You can visit the Fisheries Museum of the Atlantic,
located on the waterfront, where you can experience life
in a fishing community and discover, up close, what it is to
live by the sea. There is a living fish exhibit and wharf-side
vessels to explore. There is a $10 admission for adults and
$8 for seniors (60+).

You will be able to browse the restaurants, breweries,
artisans and unique shops on the waterfront and other points
of interest. There will be 30 minutes once we arrive back
in Lunenburg after the sailing to pick up some souvenirs
or keepsakes before we board the bus and head back to
Halifax, arriving at 4:30.

This tour is fully accessible; you should have a good
set of sea legs, and you have to be able to board a bus; we
recommend you bring a light jacket as it can get a little
chilly once we are on the open water.

Please check out the following websites: bluenose.
novascotia.ca; novascotia.com and then select: places to
go and then select: Lunenburg.

From 6 p.m. to 8 p.m.   Early Bird Dinner. Mingle in
the Hotel Restaurant for a meet and greet; individuals are
responsible for their meal costs and tip.

From 8 p.m. to 11 p.m.   Calgary House at the
Garrison Pub (The Pub is located a short 3-minute
walk across from the parking lot at the rear of the
hotel). Head to the Garrison Pub, behind the Westin
Nova Scotia, after the Early Bird Dinner. It will play
host to  Calgary House    Western Hospitality, which
Calgary is known for, out east. The Calgary Numismatic
Society has booked the pub for three hours (from 8 to 11
pm). The CNS invites all Convention goers to stop by
and enjoy some locally brewed beer, cider, and snacks.

Wednesday, July 19   Halifax Harbour Hopper Tour
Have you always wanted
to view a city with a land
and water tour all in one?
Well, we have planned just
the tour. It is called the
Halifax Harbour Hopper
Tour and is the premier
boat tour in Halifax!
All aboard this popular
boat tour for a fun and
fast-paced adventure
experience the city by
land and sea. This one-

hour tour starts with the city s historic sites, such as the
Grand Parade, Citadel Hill National Historic Site and
other downtown highlights. The adventure enters its most
exciting stage as your tour bus tums into an amphibious
craft and enters the Halifax harbour. Bring your camera for
some unique photos of both land and waterscapes. This tour
is fully narrated and is fully accessible to everyone. It is a
10-minute walk from the hotel to the departure location. If
you have a mobility issue, hop into a cab and head down to
the departure location for the tour on the boardwalk.
Please check out: www.harbourhopper.com .
Friday, July 21   George s Island Tour
If you look out your
harbour view hotel
window, you will see
Georges Island; this is a
glacial drumlin and the
largest island entirely
within the limits of Halifax
Harbour. Fort Charlotte
is situated on the island,
named after King George
IIl s wife, Charlotte. The
island is now a National
Historic Site of Canada
and is open to tours. During

the Seven Year s War, two thousand French sailors were
imprisoned on the island. Also, during the Expulsion of
the Acadians, 1,660 Acadians were held prisoner between
1755-1763. During the American Revolution, the British
re-enforced the Fort in preparation for an American
invasion, which never happened. This little island has a
great deal of history, and this tour will give you insight into
how it evolved over the years.

Discover the underground complex beneath the
Fort. A maze of tunnels once served as the bomb-
proof ammunition depot for the large guns. Guided
tours are a must lest you become lost in the passages.

La SNC a organis  la  Calgary House  lors de la Convention
2015, et tous ceux qui y ont particip  se sont  norm ment amus s,
et je suis stir que les participants feront de m me cette ann e. Tout
le monde est invit  a participer et 4 rattraper le temps perdu !
Entr e gratuite. Enti rement accessible.
Mercredi, 19 juilletle   Tour Hopper du port d Halifax

Avez-vous toujours voulu
voir une ville en faisant une
visite terrestre et aquatique en
m me temps ? Eh bien, c est
exactement ce que nous avons
pr vu. Il s agit du Tour Hopper
du port d  Halifaxet c est le tour
en bateau le plus populaire a
Halifax ! Montez a bord de
ce bateau pour une aventure
amusante et rapide - d couvrez
la ville par la terre et par la
mer. Cette visite d une heure
commence par les sites historiques de la ville, tels que le Grand
Parade, le site historique national de la colline de la Citadelle et
d autres points importants du centre-ville. L aventure entre dans
sa phase la plus excitante lorsque votre bus se transforme en
bateau amphibie et p netre dans le port d  Halifax. Apportez votre
appareil photo pour prendre des clich s uniques des paysages
terrestres et aquatiques. Cette visite est enti rement comment e
et accessible a tous. Il y a 10 minutes de marche entre | h tel et
le lieu de d part. Si vous avez des probl mes de mobilit , montez
dans un taxi et dirigez-vous vers le lieu de d part de la visite sur
la promenade. Veuillez consulter : www.harbourhopper.com .
Vendredi, 21 juillet   Visite de l ile Georges

Si vous regardez par la fen tre
de votre h tel avec vue sur
le port, vous verrez 1 ile
Georges. II s agit d un drumlin
glaciaire et de la plus grande
ile enti rement situ e dans
les limites du port d  Halifax.
Le fort Charlotte est situ  sur
Vile, nomm  en l honneur de
l pouse du roi George III,
Charlotte. Vile est aujourd  hui
un site historique national du
Canada et peut  tre visit e.
Pendant la guerre de Sept
Ans, deux mille marins frangais ont  t  emprisonn s sur | ile. De
m me, lors de l expulsion des Acadiens, | 660 d entre eux y ont
 t  retenus prisonniers entre 1755 et 1763. Pendant la R volution
ame ricaine, les Britanniques ont renforc  le fort en pr vision
dune invasion am ricaine, qui n a jamais eu lieu. Cette petite ile
a beaucoup d histoire, et cette visite vous donnera un apercu de
son  volution au fil des ans.

D couvrez le complexe souterrain situ  sous le fort. Un
labyrinthe de tunnels servait autrefois de d pdt de munitions a
l preuve des bombes pour les gros canons. Les visites guid es
sont indispensables pour ne pas se perdre dans les passages.
The CN Journal Volume 68

These 15-minute tours run every 20 minutes and are available
in English and French. You can enjoy a self-guided walking
tour of the island and explore the trail from the wharf to
the Fort and the Acadian, Mi kmaq and military points of
interest. As you look towards the city, imagine how this place
appeared when only the Mi kmaq lived here for millennia
before the European arrival.

It is just a 14-minute walk from the hotel to the departure
location, where you will enjoy a short ferry ride to the
island. If you have a mobility issue, hop into a cab and
head down to the departure location for the tour on the
boardwalk. Dress for the weather, as the visit is almost
entirely outdoors. The ferry to the island is designed as a
flex ticket, allowing you an open-ended return time. The
terrain is hilly, with designated walkways.

Please check out: www.ambassatours.com and then
select Tours, then: Visit Georges Island .
Friday, July 21   Grafton Street Dinner Theatre
On Friday evening, jump on a
bus and experience a unique
dining experience- food,
music and comedy all at the
same time at the Grafton Street
Dinner Theatre! Show title:
Back to the East Coast, where
you are invited to the final
round of the Best of the East
where contestants representing
the four Atlantic Provinces
compete to prove their region
is supreme. Cheer on your

favourite province while tapping your feet to some of the
best music that NS, NB, PEI and NFLD have to offer!

The Dinner Theatre meal is a three-course meal, with
two choices for the starters and four options for the entr e
and two choices for dessert, graftonsdinnertheatre.com .

The theatre is fully accessible. (You do have to be able to
board a bus.)

Saturday, July 22 - Walk About on The Halifax
Harbourfront

This is not an organized tour, just a block of time that you
can use to wander the harbourfront tourist attractions. Why
not ask your friends to join you? Suggested stops:
  Canadian Museum of Immigration at Pier 21  
Adult: $17.80; Youth: $11.80; www.pier21.ca .
  Halifax Seaport Market (over 50 vendors)   Free
www.halifaxfarmersmark.com .
  Art Gallery of Nova Scotia   Adult: $14; Youth:
$5.75; agns.ca .
  Maritime Museum of the Atlantic   Adult: $6;
Youth: $3.60; martimemusem.novascotia.ca .
As the Convention draws closer and closer, please check for
further information on our website, www.rena.ca, under the
Events menu.
Looking forward to seeing you in Halifax!
Games Williston

PREVIOUSLY UNPUBLISHED
BY ROB TURNER
1858 CENT WORKING, DIES, PART 4. ERCNA, FCNRS, #20948.

[Editor s note: This is the second article in an 8-part series which includes all the dies used to strike Provincial
Canadian large cents 1858 and 1859 W9/8 discovered since the author s second book (2008). The author has
requested that the die description pages be in the same format as his books for better consistency. ]
T he series of articles on the 1858 and 1859 W9/8 one-

cent reverse dies discovered since 2008 continue
with the first three 1858 reverse dies from group RC,
specifically Dies RC29, RC30, and RC31.

In Part 1, we discussed the problems encountered while
sinking these one-cent dies in that the delicate maple vine
and leaf stems on the reverse punch rapidly deteriorated.
Readers will remember that while sinking the fourth die, half
the stem to Leaf #9 broke away from the punch, so every die
sunk after the third die inherited this broken leaf stem. Then
starting with the fifth die sunk, a section of the maple vine
broke away from the punch adjacent to Leaf #13. Thus each
die from the fifth die onward shows this very visible vine
break that the engraver usually left unrepaired.

All die group RC dies have two breaks in the maple
vine, one adjacent to Leaf #13 and another next to Leaf
#7. For all the known RC dies, the mint engraver manually
repaired the broken stem to Leaf #9 with varying results.

Die RC29 actually shows that the engraver also made a
half-hearted attempt to repair the vine break at Leaf #13.
Also, for ease of reference, we numbered the maple leaves
on the reverse design, starting at the top of the coin and
moving clockwise.
NUMISMATIC LITERATURE
Zio LT cilisngs

BY ALAN ROY
#17134
Coin Collectors Handbook
The Canadian Association of Numismatic Dealers
was established in January 1975. The impetus of its

formation was to provide a code of conduct for coin
dealers and establish a system to help resolve disagreements
between dealers and collectors. But the organization
provided other benefits for its members as well. CAND
ran its own coin shows and auctions and made efforts to
advance the hobby through promotion and education.

Many members of CAND had experience with
publishing auction catalogues and numismatic references.
One of the best-known was Bill Cross, who was the owner
of The Charlton Press and served as president of CAND
for a time. With all this experience, it is not surprising that
one of the strategies adopted to promote the hobby was to
publish the Coin Collectors Handbook.

The small booklet was first printed in 1979. The
organization gave away copies of the book to promote coin
collecting and raise awareness of CAND. It was created
to bring a new generation to the hobby. It includes all the
information a new collector would need: a quick history
of the hobby, advice on
starting a coin collection,
how to deal with coin clubs
and coin dealers, and an
overview of coin valuation.

New collectors also got
some advice about storing
and preserving their coins.

One section describing
the conditions of coins
includes a detailed
description of the terms
  proof, specimen, and
proof-like, describing the
qualities of coins. It then
describes the different
terms numismatists use to
grade a coin s condition.

Another section, called
 Major Canadian Coin
Types , breaks down all
circulating coins from one
cent to $100 gold into their
major design types. This list
would have been handy for
novice numismatists who
decided to collect Canada s

coins by type rather than trying to get each date in various
coin series.

The booklet is rounded out with a list of useful
numismatic periodicals and their contact information and
a bibliography of recommended coin catalogues that would
be useful to the novice numismatist.

The work was based on Welcome to Coin Collecting!
The Worlds Oldest Hobby, an introduction to numismatics
published by Western Publishing of Racine, Wisconsin,
in 1969. CAND member Robert Aaron, who was a
numismatic columnist for the Toronto Star at the time,
edited the original text for a Canadian audience.

The organization felt it was time to make such a
publication available to the public. A news release about the
booklet that appeared in The Canadian Numismatic Journal
in 1980 states this:
The release of the booklet by CAND for free distri-
bution marks a significant financial commitment to
public education by the Association. It is the first time
a project of this scale has been undertaken within the
numismatic Hobby in Canada.

There doesn t seem to be
any information about how
well the public received the
book, but it must have been
successful enough to justify
a second edition published
two years later.

The latter edition
expanded and improved
the  Major Canadian
Coin Types  section with
photographs and listed
various CAND members 
names and addresses.

In a time before the
Internet and easy access to
information, it must have
been wonderful for the
curious public to have an
easily accessible source of
information for our hobby.
We may never know how
many collectors started in
the hobby because of one
of these little books, but
we should thank CAND for
their foresight. aay
The CN Journal Volume 68

members and guests were invited to a free private tour on
March 18. A free public educational symposium entitled
 Power, Identity and Alexander the Great  will be held
at the Nickle Galleries on April 29-30 to celebrate the
closing of the special gallery. Included are six expert
speakers on the topic. Pre-registration is required and can
be completed by going to the weblink nickle.ucalgary.
ca/event/symposium-power-identity-and-alexander-the-
great/ .

Waterloo Coin Society Incentive for
Volunteer Work

As an incentive, we offer all member volunteers a $5
TimCard  for every two-hour block of time worked.
Tim Hortons coffee and doughnuts will also be available
for volunteers during the day.

New British Columbia Study Group: Ancient
History & Coin Group: The Roman and
Byzantine Empires

A small group has formed to discover and learn facts
about ancient history through Roman and Byzantine
coins. Purchasing coins is not necessary, and beginners
are welcome. The group theme is  Coins: Markers of
Time . The group meets at the MLA office in Qualicum
Beach, Vancouver Island, on the third Thursday of
every month with a start time of 2 pm. High-quality
well-illustrated catalogues have been donated to give
to members. For more information, contact Cathy
MacFarlane by phone at (250) 594-2260 or by email
fiona3@shaw.ca.
Brett Triche

The CN Journal Volume 68

IN_THE_NEWS BY HENRY NIENHUIS
FRCNA, FCNRS, FONA, LM.#430

(a
Archives International Auctions   Auction 85-B, May 23, 2023; Lot 36
I t is interesting to note just how long the Bank of Canada will study significant changes to our banknotes prior to actually

implementing the change. An example of this is the  Printer s Essay  of a 50-dollar Bird Series (1988) banknote that recently was
consigned to an Archives International Auction, River Edge NJ, (www.archivesinternational.com) at the end of May of this year.

Dr Robert Schwartz noted in the catalogue description for lot 36,  Bank of Canada, 1988, $50,  Printers Essay  DuraNote
Polymer Plastic Banknote.  The test note, graded by PMG as Gem Uncirculated 65 EPQ, sold for US$6,000 plus juice. Which
appears to be a bargain described as  very possibly the finest known.

Instead of the normal paper stock with security features that this note was originally printed on when it circulated in
late 1989, it is printed as a test (without the  50  optical device) on DuraNote, a composite petroleum-based hydrocarbon
substrate, as a paper substitute. The substrate, built with 21 ultra-thin layers of polypropylene film along with adhesives and
coatings to make a printable surface, was promoted by US Mobil Oil (and Canadian engineering company AGRA Vadeko) as
a cleaner, longer-lasting alternative to existing substrates such as Tyvek. However, after a series of tests using regular printing
plates from a number of countries, it was never brought to market due to the complexities in the production process.

The note in the auction, a Snowy Owl $50, P-98tp, BC-59aPE, with Thiessen | Crow signatures, has SPECIMEN overprinted
in large black outline typeface on both sides. The back has blue ink graffiti (11?) in the upper right along with JUL 24 1994
stamped in red ink (smeared). This implies the test took place in 1994 about 17 years before a polymer note was released.

The CN Journal Volume 68
COMMUNION TOKENS OF HALIFAX
AND_DARTMOUTH

By ANGUS SUTHERLAND
#24054

he peninsula on which the city of Halifax stands
| was called Chebucto by the Mi kmaq. In 1749, the

Hon. Edward Cornwallis landed at that strategic
spot with some 2,500 settlers intent on establishing a
permanent fortified settlement for the British crown. The
community was soon named  Halifax  in honour of Lord
Halifax, President of the British Board of Trade.

As in every place where a colony was established,
the settlers came with their traditions, including the
desire to worship God in their particular way. Churches
were established as time passed, and four Presbyterian
congregations eventually used specific metal Communion
Tokens in the city.
1749 St. Matthew s

As the Church of England was understood to be the official
church of the colonies, St. Paul s Anglican Church was
established in 1749, and work began on a building for
worship. But the Anglican form of worship did not have
a claim on the hearts of all the settlers. A group calling
themselves the Protestant Dissenters established a
congregation as well. They began work on a building to be
known as Mather s Meeting House, named for the Puritan,
Cotton Mather. The congregation was made up primarily of
Presbyterians and Congregationalists.

The congregation s first minister was the Rev. Aaron
Cleveland, great-grandfather to U.S. President Grover
Cleveland.  Mather s  first years were difficult for a church
holding mostly to Congregationalist ideals, particularly

in finding pastors. The American desire for independence
from Britain worked against the church, whose first
ministers were all from the United States. Looking to
improve its image, the congregation became known for a
while by the strange name of St. Mather s (one wonders
what a Puritan would think of being canonised a saint), and
then finally, St. Matthew s.

In 1784 they called their first Presbyterian minister,
the Rev. Thomas Russell, a Scot who arrived via the
US. Mr Russell s departure in 1787 due to internal strife
encouraged the congregation to sit down and work out a
constitution that would enable the Congregationalists and
Presbyterians to live and worship together despite their
differences. Although the congregation did not officially
become Presbyterian until 1841, voting then to unite with
the Church of Scotland, all but one of the ministers from
1784 were Presbyterians.

Under the next minister, the Rev. Andrew Brown
(1787-1795), St. Matthew s gained a previously unknown
respectability in the city. He was followed by the Rev.
Archibald Gray (1795-1826) and the Rev. John Scott
(1826-1863), who brought the congregation finally into
the fold of the Church of Scotland. The Rev. George Grant
(1863-1877) led the congregation into the union forming
the Presbyterian Church in Canada in 1875. In 1925 St.
Matthew s voted over 75 percent in favour of entering the
United Church of Canada. St. Matthew s and the city of
Halifax celebrated its 250th anniversary in 1999.

Early St. Matthew s United Church, Halifax NS,
Communion Tokens from 18th to 19th Century.
Volume 68
The CN Journal

Token 1 of St. Matthew s was struck when the
congregation s first Presbyterian minister, the Rev. Thomas
Russell, arrived in 1784. The letters PCH have been
assumed to stand for Presbyterian Church Halifax. But
because the congregation did not enter the Presbyterian
fold until 1841, believing the letters to stand for Protestant
Church Halifax is a better conjecture. Perhaps the presiding
minister, a Presbyterian, chose the initials on the belief that
the congregation would soon decide to be Presbyterian. The
token s reverse sports an attractive rendition of the burning
bush, a symbol Presbyterians have used from the time of
the Reformation.

Token 2 is considered a mystery. Dated 1786, just two
years after the first token, it is attributed to St. Matthew s
because there was no other Protestant Church in the city
at that time. There is no historical reason given in the
congregational records for this token. One wonders why the
token was struck, especially since the token of 1784 is more
available to collectors today. Perhaps the best guess is that
the tokens of 1784 were temporarily misplaced, and striking
of the tokens of 1786 had begun when the first tokens were
rediscovered. It is also possible that this is the first token
used at St. Matthews and that the token dated 1784 was a
second token antedated to the beginning of Presbyterian
ministry there. Token 2 is unique to Canadian Communion
Tokens in that the chalice is outlined rather than represented
in full. This feature is also known on some  M reaux de
Communion  used in France in the mid-1800s.

Tokens 3 and 4 are believed to date from the time that
the congregation took the name St. Matthew s in 1817.
Token 3 (published here for the first time) is mis-spelled
 ST. MATHEW S  (one T) and presumably was recalled
when the mis-spelling was noticed. Two examples are
known to the author. Token 4 has the correct spelling with
two T s. These tokens name the congregation but still avoid
declaring a denominational affiliation. The reverse features
a chalice and the common Scripture reading,  This do in
remembrance of me .
CHT COS

1818 Communion Token from the Relief Church in
Halifax.
1818 Relief Church / St. Andrew s

A congregation of the Associate Presbyterian Church was
established in Halifax, but due to a dispute relating to a  candid
investigation on the part of the United Presbyteries of Nova
Scotia , a group of about thirty members left and formed a
congregation of their own, their building being completed in
1817. The congregation applied to be received by the Synod of
the Relief Church in Scotland, which was unanimously approved.

The first minister sent to serve the congregation was the
Rev. Mr Paterson, who arrived in May of 1818. He arranged
with the Session to have the first observance of the Lord s
Supper in October of that year, and tokens were struck. After
that Communion, Mr Paterson, apparently appointed only to
get things started, returned to Scotland and was replaced by
the Rev. Thomas McInnis. Mr McInnis left  very suddenly
and unexpectedly  in June of 1820. An interim ministry
was carried out by the Rev. Dr Burns of St. John, New
Brunswick, who moved the congregation into the Church of
Scotland late in that year.

In 1821, the congregation took the name St. Andrew s and
called, as their first Church of Scotland minister, the Rev. John
Martin. In 1844, St. Andrew s gave polite audience to Dr Burns
again as he came to argue on behalf of the Free Church of
Scotland, but the congregation remained with the Established
Church. St. Andrew s became part of the Presbyterian Church
in Canada in 1875. In 1917, St. Andrew s merged with Coburg
Road Presbyterian Church, retaining the name St. Andrew s,
and in 1925 voted 268 to 145 to join the United Church.

Token 5, belonging to St. Andrew s, is dated 1818, and
the initials RCH stand for Relief Church Halifax. The token
continued to be used after the congregation entered the
Church of Scotland.
1843 Poplar Grove / Park Street

In 1843 in the growing city of Halifax, a congregation of
the Presbyterian Church of Nova Scotia, connected with
the United Secession Church of Scotland, was established.

Poplar Grove Church Communion Tokens dated 1843 in
lead and later in white metal.

The congregation, named Poplar Grove, called as its first
minister the Rev. Peter MacGregor, who served from 1843
to 1868. The token was struck during the first year of his
ministry. Under his leadership, the congregation took part
in the union of 1860, forming the Presbyterian Church of
the Lower Provinces of British North America.

He was followed by the Rev. Allan Simpson (1868 
1898), who led them into the 1875 union forming the
Presbyterian Church in Canada. After outgrowing its
building, the congregation established itself in a new
building on Park Street in 1884 and was renamed Park
Street Presbyterian Church. In 1925, during the ministry
of the Rev. A. L. Fraser, the congregation voted to join the
United Church and was closed, merging with St. John s
(see below). Mr Fraser became minister of the enlarged St.
John s United Church and remained for a further four years.

The tokens of Poplar Grove Church name the Rev.
Peter MacGregor and are dated from his call. Token 6 is
made of lead. Token 7 was probably made to supplement
the original lead tokens and is made of white metal. The
lettering is a bit larger, which is particularly noticeable on
the reverse.
1863 St. John s

In 1863, a second congregation of the Presbyterian Church
of the Lower Provinces of British North America was
established in Halifax and named St. John s. However,
it was not the city s first congregation with this name. A
previous church was named St. John s, but it joined the Free
Church in 1843 and, at that time, took the name Chalmers.
There was no connection between the two congregations.
The Rev. Thomas Cumming was called and served
from 1863 to 1866, the token being struck in the first year
of his ministry. Mr Cumming was followed by the Rev.
John Forrest, the minister from 1866 to 1881. During Mr
Forrest s ministry, the congregation became part of the
Presbyterian Church in Canada. In 1925, the congregation
decided to become part of the United Church of Canada,
amalgamating with Park Street Church but keeping the
name St. John s. As they were without a minister, the

Communion Tokens of St. John s, Halifax, and St. James,
Dartmouth NS.

Rev. John MacKinnon having left in 1924, the minister
of Park Street became minister to the newly amalgamated
congregation.

Token 8 is dated from the congregation s founding in
1863 and is of white metal.

Halifax is unusual in that all the Presbyterian
congregations that used specific metal tokens for
Communion chose to enter the United Church in 1925.
They continue in the present St. Matthew s, St. Andrew s,
and St. John s United Churches.

Those who wished to be continuing Presbyterians,
including people from all the above congregations,
purchased a building from the Methodists and chose the
name St. David s. Other congregations of the Presbyterian
Church in Canada have been established since that time.
Dartmouth, St. James

Scottish stonemasons were brought to Nova Scotia to help
build the Shubenacadie Canal, many of them arriving in
what is now Dartmouth in 1826. The Rev. James Morrison
also arrived that year and organised a congregation of the
Church of Scotland. The first building opened in January
1829 and held close to 300 congregants. Mr Morrison
left in 1830 to teach school, and after a vacancy, the Rev.
Alexander Romans arrived in 1834.

In 1868, it was decided that a new building was in order,
and the new structure, which continues to be the place of
worship for the congregation, was completed in 1871. St.
James entered the Presbyterian Union of 1875 and, in 1925,
under the ministry of the Rev. J. W. A. Nicholson, chose to
enter the United Church of Canada.
Tokens 9 and 10 are from this congregation, having
identical obverses but variant reverses.

Token 10 is slightly smaller in all respects, but the most
noticeable difference is on the reverse: the letter I of the
word  IN  is directly over the first upright of the letter N in
 REMEMBRANCE .

(NOTE: Token 9 is as illustrated in Bowman and
photographed in Charlton, and token 10 is added here as
the variety.)
POTTOTCCONNLCT

COMMUNIQUE

2023 $20 Fine Silver Coin   150th
Anniversary of Prince Edward Island Joining
Confederation

Designed by artist Bonnie Ross, your coin s reverse
features an engraved collage of iconic sights and
symbols of Prince Edward Island in honour
of the 150th anniversary of its joining
Confederation (1873-2023). The first
lighthouse in Prince Edward Island, the Point
Prim Lighthouse, appears in the foreground;

it sits atop the shield from the Arms of
Prince Edward Island, which is flanked
by another official provincial emblem, the
Lady s Slipper (Cypripedium acaule) flower.
Behind the lighthouse and beneath the view
of the Confederation Bridge, a map

outline of the island shows the
Confederation Trail. The obverse
features the effigy of Queen
Elizabeth II by Susanna Blunt.
The obverse also bears a special
marking that includes four pearls
symbolizing the four effigies that
have graced Canadian coins and the
double date of her reign.

2023 $20 Fine Silver Coin   National
Indigenous Peoples Day

In celebration of National Indigenous Peoples Day,
the reverse design combines the art of Megan
Currie, English River First Nation, Myrna
Pokiak (Agnaviak), Inuvialuit Settlement
Region and Jennine Krauchi, Red River
M tis; their joint creation stunningly
combines their expressions of First
Nations, Inuit, and M tis cultures, art
and traditions and is an open invitation

to celebrate National Indigenous
Peoples Day. The obverse features the
effigy of Queen Elizabeth II by
Susanna Blunt. The obverse
also bears a special marking
that includes four pearls
symbolizing the four
effigies that have
graced Canadian coins and
the double date of her reign.

BOOK.REVIEW,
Trade Tokens of Ontario

arlier this year, Lorne
E Barnes released his much-
anticipated reference work:

Trade Tokens of Ontario. To call
it an upgrade to the Fred Bowman
works of the same title (1st Edition,
1966; 2nd Edition, 1972; and a
later 1982 Supplement) is a bit of
an understatement.

It is no longer an 8vo format
booklet but rather a hardcover,
immense and comprehensive
update to Bowman s work,
painstakingly documented and
detailed with full-size colour
images of a large number of the
tokens listed. The author s intent
was to stay as true to the original
reference as possible;  [My book]
was made possible because of the
efforts of the late Fred
Bowman 50 years
ago, who introduced
the numbering
system still used by
collectors today. I
felt that there was
no need to introduce
a new layout and
numbering system
when collectors are
using a system that
already works.

The decision to
reproduce the token
images to size makes
a great deal of sense
when you see a series laid out in front of you, albeit it does
make reading the smaller 18 mm (about the size of a 10-cent
piece) half-tone images a bit hard at times. But this task is
easier because the full legend is given in the description below.
Barnes also includes period images to give the collector a
sense of historical context in which these tokens would be
used in daily commerce between the 1890s and 1920s.
Made possible by a grant from the J Douglas Ferguson Historical Foundation.
ne

The author is clearly passionate
about this numismatic area   as
you can see on every one of the
808 pages. His devotion to the
topic is reflected in the extensive
research and detailed information
that is presented, as well as in the
clear and accessible writing style
that makes the subject matter
simple and easy to understand.

A coloured version of the
Bowman reference was needed,
and after discussions with several
interested parties, I decided to start
work on the project,  Barnes told
CCN. It is a valuable resource
that anyone with an interest in the
merchant due bills of Ontario will
appreciate. The book provides
a wealth of information, with a

key   explaining the
compact description
style, making it clear
and easy to understand
even for those with
little or no background
in numismatics  
highly recommended
for token collectors
and bibliophiles.
